name: SPEAKER, Mr
text:
—I present the report of the Australian Delegation to the 104th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Jakarta from 15 to 21 October 2000, and the bilateral visit to Vietnam from 22 to 27 October 2000. I want to make a few brief comments and then allow others in the delegation to provide more detail.
The Australian delegation played a major role at the IPU conference and was instrumental in formulating two of the resolutions adopted by the conference. The IPU is going through a critical period. If it is to remain relevant as a legitimate forum for international parliamentary debates, in my view and that of many others it must undertake a series of reforms to ensure that it operates within its budget and that the conference format makes for more effective use of time and limited resources. The Australian IPU group will do what it can to ensure that this occurs and that the IPU continues to be a respected and effective international institution.
The bilateral visit to Vietnam was particularly successful. The official program included meetings with the prime minister, the foreign minister, the planning minister and the chairman of the national assembly, as well as the chairmen from several other provincial councils and committees. The delegation also met with a number of Australian business people operating in Vietnam. These meetings enabled the delegation to discuss a range of issues, including the strength of the bilateral relationship; the progress of economic reform in Vietnam, in particular opening up the economy and increasing the level of foreign investment; the aftermath of the floods in the central and southern regions; the role played by Australian aid in various developmental projects, including the successfully completed My Thuan bridge; and the role played by both countries in the Asia-Pacific region.
The discussions were frank and informative and left the delegation with a very clear impression that Vietnam is making steady, if measured, progress towards the reform of its economy and access to its markets. Of particular interest to the delegation was the opportunity to see at first-hand the impact of Australian investment and the benefits to the social economy of Australian aid expenditure. Overall, it was a very informative and rewarding visit. The relationship between both countries is strong, and the delegation came away with a very positive impression about future relations between Vietnam and Australia. I commend the report to the House.

name: Crosio, Janice, MP
text:
—I, too, in following those remarks, would like to comment very briefly on the IPU conference. I take on board, as do the other delegates, the changes that are occurring and will occur, not only to the structure of the IPU but also to its charter. One of the things I would like to mention in the House is that we have already commenced that process through the meeting of women parliamentarians. When we meet at the next IPU conference we will be adopting a different format. One interesting part that is very dear to my heart is that, following the executive council meeting—and it is noted on page 21 of the report—the council took note of a report by Mrs Murti from Indonesia, who chaired the proceedings of the women's meeting, when she called on all national parliaments to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I again appeal to the government to take that on board, bearing in mind that many national parliaments around the world have now taken that step.  
Without covering the IPU in detail, I would like particularly to turn to Vietnam. Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your leadership there. It was a very trying time: we seemed to be perpetually and continually on the move. I found it very interesting to see what has happened with Australia's aid in Vietnam. We do realise and acknowledge that, over a period of four years, until 2002, some $236 million in aid has been pledged to Vietnam. On top of that, there is $11 million per year from Australian funding for regional programs, NGOs and emergency assistance. I can assure the parliament, as I and the other delegates have seen at first-hand, that they are certainly spending the money very wisely and well. I was particularly impressed in Hanoi where we visited a university where a special project is being undertaken by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. Scientists are researching various diseases with bananas, cucumbers, papaya, et cetera, and are working hand in hand with the university people there. I think it is an excellent project. 
The other project I was particularly impressed with—and I know you mentioned the bridge project, Mr Speaker, at My Thuan—was when we went into the rural areas to see the work being done by some of our Australian aid workers. On that early morning flight we visited Tra My, one of the four mountainous districts in Quang Nam province. We were able to witness at first-hand what the RIDEF project is doing there to alleviate rural poverty through investment in small scale, social and economic infrastructure in relatively poor and underequipped rural areas and provinces. I think the parliament can be very proud of how our money is being spent and of how well it is being spent. We are making a difference there. I think all of Vietnam is now acknowledging Australia as very much a major player in assistance to them. In particular, I think through the IPU conference, with our delegates being on the ground there, we were able to assist and help the Indonesian and Australian relationship. I thank all the staff who were there with us.

name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
text:
—On behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Cracking down on copycats: enforcement of copyright in Australia, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.
Ordered that the report be printed.
—This report of the House of Representatives Standing committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is the result of a prolonged study of the enforcement of copyright in Australia. Terms of reference for the inquiry were received from the Attorney-General in March 1999 and the committee commenced its work. In September 1999, when the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Bill 1999 was introduced into the House, the Attorney-General referred that bill to the committee for inquiry and report. The two inquiries complemented each other in part, because they both reflect a focus that is timely—that is, on copyright enforcement in a manner that is appropriate to the information age.
The current inquiry followed a growing number of claims by some Australian industries that copyright owners and other members of the community are being deprived of income that is rightly theirs, because of infringement of copyright. Perhaps because copyright is an intangible form of property, its infringement or theft is not regarded with the same seriousness in the community as we regard thefts of other kind of property. It is also fair to say that copyright law is not well understood. This may also contribute to the broad lack of concern about infringement. Current attitudes to copyright law need to change. Many of the new jobs underpinning our economy involve the creation, manipulation, storage and use of information. It follows that adequate protection of intellectual property, including copyright, is essential for individual owners and also for our future prosperity. 
In undertaking its inquiry the committee first surveyed the nature and extent of copyright infringement in Australia. It has concluded that, despite a perception in some industries that copyright infringement is rife, in fact it is low by international standards. I note in passing that evidence on whether and to what extent organised crime groups are involved in copyright infringement was conflicting. Most government bodies were not aware of such involvement, while some industry bodies told the committee they knew of some organised criminal groups that were involved. Whatever the frequency or source of infringement, the fact remains that it is a costly and significant burden to the economy. The committee heard evidence from copyright owners and industry groups that infringement is likely to increase in the future, especially in the electronic domain.
Facilitating proof of copyright ownership in both civil and criminal proceedings is the focus of one of the committee's key recommendations. The evidence received by the committee showed that proof of ownership has been a major stumbling block in actions for infringement. In response, the committee has advocated the use of an affidavit that outlines the chain of title, thus giving rise to a rebuttable presumption of ownership. The committee preferred this simplification over the reintroduction of a system of registration for copyright.
The committee has sought to strengthen criminal sanctions for infringement by advocating sentencing guidelines for copyright offences in the form of guideline judgments and by amendments to tighten the offence provisions in the Copyright Act. One recommendation aimed at deterring repeat offenders is for the provision of increased penalties for people who are convicted of subsequent offences. The committee also recommended new offences to target end-user piracy and bootlegging at public venues.
The committee was concerned to increase access by copyright owners to civil enforcement action as well as to enhance the effectiveness of such action. The main recommendation in this regard is for the establishment of a small claims jurisdiction within the Federal Magistrates Court to hear claims of infringement. The committee has also recommended a limited power of seizure to assist in the pre-trial process as well as calling for consideration of a system of statutory damages as an alternative to the requirement to prove actual damage. The committee considered it appropriate to lift the veil when enforcing copyright judgments against corporate infringers so that owners may recover damages from the directors of companies that are found to be engaged in piracy or bootlegging. Last, the committee examined the role played by government agencies and recommended some changes in this regard. 
In conclusion, I hope that through this report, Cracking down on copycats, we can contribute to more effective enforcement of copyright throughout Australia and better education of all those involved. I thank all those individuals involved in the report, those who made submissions and the members of the committee for working in a constructive way to arrive at these recommendations. I thank the secretariat staff—in particular Andrew Grimm; the secretary, Catherine Cornish; and the administrative officer, Frances Wilson—for the work undertaken in support of the committee during this inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

name: Kerr, Duncan, MP
text:
— Thank you, Mr Speaker. This report of the House Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Cracking down on copycats is a very important report. Firstly, I want to echo the words of the chair of that committee in congratulating those involved in the secretariat and on the committee. This was a very cooperative committee. The chair and deputy chair worked very well together to ensure that the procedures of the committee were streamlined. They worked very effectively. We had a wide opportunity to debate this internally. I think this is a vital report. 
Over a long period of time, this parliament's attention has been focused on the substantive copyright law—making certain that we have legislation in place that correctly identifies legal rights and enables the remuneration of those who are rights holders. But giving people rights in law is only part of the responsibility of this legislature; the other part is making certain that those rights can be effectively enforced. There has been great weakness in terms of the capacity to translate a theoretical right into a practical right. This committee's starting point was that there needs to be some significant public education in relation to the importance of these copyright issues to make certain that the community understands the rights and responsibilities in relation to holders of copyright and how those rights can be enforced. 
A number of recommendations go to the ease of proving matters—removing the procedural and technical difficulties that have hitherto made it difficult for copyright holders to establish their entitlements. There are some self-help measures included in this which particularly go to those who run stalls or flog goods outside concerts or the like which would enable copyright holders to seize those goods, but it would also give anyone who contests that right an opportunity at a later stage to have their case heard.
There are some practical measures in establishing a small claims tribunal, and this government has introduced a magistracy to the Federal Court. Hitherto, its focus has been in relation to streamlining the effectiveness of the Family Court. But, if we are going to establish a magistracy, there is no reason we cannot include within its jurisdiction a small claims jurisdiction of the kinds which operate in the various states and territories—and we suggested as models along the lines of the Tasmanian or ACT models—which would allow for small copyright matters to be heard in that very informal way.
 (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for statements on this report has expired.

name: Wilkie, Kim, MP
text:
—I move:
That this House:
(1)	congratulates Iran regarding the completion of acknowledged democratic elections and the work of the new Majlis;
(2)	nevertheless regrets that Iran's reputation continues to be marred by questions of human rights and denial of religious freedom, most particularly the persecution of Baha'is and the renewal of the death sentences of Mr Hedayat Kashefi Najafabadi and Mr Sirus Zabihi-Moghaddam, and the inception of another against Mr Manuchehr Khulusi;
(3)	furthermore notes the persistent gaoling of numerous Baha'is for their religious beliefs and widespread discrimination in property, education, employment, civil and political rights;
(4)	acknowledges grave concern for the fate of 13 members of the Jewish community presently in custody in Iranian prisons and facing charges of espionage; and
(5)	urges Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran.
This parliament has debated the situation of the Baha'is and religious freedom in Iran on a number of occasions, most recently in motions put before the parliament by the member for Reid and also by the member for North Sydney. The motions have been debated at length by some distinguished members of this House, including the member for Aston, the member for Hindmarsh and the member for Franklin. I welcome their involvement in those discussions. The general situation of the Baha'is in Iran is quite appalling. To give some credence to that, I would like to advise the House of a number of areas where they are unable to practise their faith and the resulting distress that it causes the community.
It is a matter of deep regret that Iran's conduct in this area continues to justify the concern of this parliament and, indeed, of the international community as a whole. The Baha'i community in Iran numbers around 300,000. It is the largest non-Muslim religious minority in that country, yet it continues to face systematic persecution by the Iranian authorities. Currently 10 Baha'is are imprisoned and one is under house arrest in Iran because of their religious beliefs. A number of these are under the death sentence. Baha'is have been systematically excluded from employment and higher education in Iran. An entire generation of Baha'i youth has been prevented from entering Iran's tertiary institutions. The Iranian government has sought to prevent Baha'is from undertaking their own education of Baha'i youth by arresting and intimidating teachers who voluntarily undertook to provide education the government has sought to deny them. These efforts have been unsuccessful and the Baha'is continue to run a correspondence based Baha'i Institute for Higher Education.
The most holy places of the Baha'i faith, Baha'i community properties and Baha'i cemeteries have been desecrated, destroyed or confiscated. No attempt has been made to restore or compensate the Baha'i community, as called for by the international community. Baha'is continue to be denied the right to bury their deceased relatives with dignity, being forced to use unmarked graves in areas of waste land. The `spiritual assemblies' of the Baha'is, elected lay councils of nine men and women which fulfil some of the roles of clergy in other religions, are sacred to the Baha'is and membership of these has been banned by the Iranian government. This is a significant restriction on the freedom of Baha'is to practice their religion in accordance with the tenets of their faith. It is also a denial of the freedom of assembly and association that every individual possesses. The freedom of association of Baha'is is regularly impeded by government interference in devotional and educational meetings of the community. Mr Maurice Copithorne, the UN Special Representative on the Human Rights Situation in Iran, in his latest report, notes continuing acts of intimidation carried out in order to prevent Baha'is from participating in religious or educational activities and an apparent increase in the number of short-term arrests and suspended sentences to be applied only if the accused participate again in Baha'i gatherings. 
Baha'is encounter difficulties in obtaining passports, impeding their freedom of movement. One improvement that should be noted is that, although Iran does not recognise the right of Baha'is to marry in accordance with their own religious traditions, by removing questions on religion at the time of registration of marriage, Iran has now put in place measures to allow administrative acknowledgment of the marital status of a Baha'i couple. This removes a longstanding civil discrimination affecting the legality of family life of Baha'is and their inheritance rights and is to be welcomed. The treatment of the Baha'is in Iran is undoubtedly a key issue in terms of both religious freedom and human rights for that country.
In Australia, 12,000 Baha'is live in full religious freedom. They, like other Australians, are not subject to intrusive inquiry into their beliefs, nor to penalties because of their faith. They are a diverse religious community of a wide variety of backgrounds who seek to give expression to their religious convictions by worship and by service to society. Their beliefs include principles such as oneness of God, the oneness of humanity, the equality of men and women and the independent investigation of religious truth. They are known for their commitment to the promotion of peace. In 1986, the Australian Baha'i community received a peace award from the UN Secretary-General for its work in the promotion of peace during the International Year of Peace. In my electorate the members of the Baha'i community share my deep concern for their fellow believers in Iran. Many Australian Baha'is have relatives in Iran, including some among those imprisoned in Iran for their beliefs. They live in constant anxiety as to the fate of their relatives.
Recently there were parliamentary elections in Iran. The motion that is currently before the House also addresses those elections. The elections demonstrated the strong commitment of the Iranian people to parliamentary democracy and their aspiration for civil and political freedoms. Iran is to be congratulated for that achievement. It is to be hoped that Iran's parliament will be given the freedom to carry out its responsibilities as the representative of the people of Iran.
In relation to the death sentences and penalties that have been imposed by the courts, this motion also refers to the cases of Mr Hedayat Kashefi Najafabadi, Mr Sirus Zabihi-Moghaddam and Mr Manuchehr Khulusi, who have been sentenced to death because of their involvement in organising religious classes for Baha'i youth. I have been informed by representatives of the Australian Baha'i community that, in the cases of Mr Najafabadi and Mr Moghaddam, these sentences were recently set aside as unsound by the Iranian Supreme Court and that their cases were referred back to a lower court. This is the third time that even the Iranian Supreme Court has felt the injustice of these cases and quashed lower court decisions imposing death sentences on these men.
It is time that these men were released. They were first sentenced to death in February 1998, along with another Baha'i, Mr Ruhullah Rawhani, who was in fact executed by the regime for his beliefs. In March 1998, the Supreme Court rejected the verdicts, finding no evidence against them and that their religious beliefs did not provide justification for a death sentence. The case was referred back to a lower court. In September 1998, a lower Islamic Revolutionary Court again sentenced them to death, despite the findings of the Supreme Court. The men were tried again—this time with a lawyer of their choice, which had been denied to them previously. In January 1999, the Supreme Court again overturned the verdict for the second time because of what were referred to as `technical deficiencies'. In November 1999, the men were again sentenced to death by the same lower court, leading to the latest Supreme Court decision quashing the sentence. Only one action should be taken in this case and that is the immediate release of these men. 
Mr Manuchehr Khulusi was also sentenced to death in Mashhad but later released. No action appears to have been taken to revoke the death sentence which continues to hang over his head. There are other Baha'i prisoners facing similar fates. I would like to read an extract from the Iranian court decision in regard to Mr Dhabihullah Mahrami, recognised by Amnesty International as a prisoner of conscience, to make clear what his case is about and why he is imprisoned for life in Iran. It states:
Concerning the charges against Mr Dhabihullah Mahrami ... ie denouncing the blessed religion of Islam and accepting the beliefs of the wayward Baha'i sect (national apostasy), in light of his clear confessions to the fact that he accepted the wayward Baha'i sect at the age of maturity, later accepted Islam for a period of seven years, and then returned to the aforementioned sect and because of the fact that, despite the most tremendous efforts of this court to guide him and encourage him to repent for having committed the most grievous sin, he remains firm in his baseless beliefs, he has, on three consecutive meetings, while being of sound body and mind and in absolute control, announced his allegiance to the principles of Baha'ism ... and he is not willing to repent for having committed this sin ... the accused is sentenced to death because of being an apostate. Furthermore ... in light of the fact that he does not have any Muslim heirs, a verdict is issued for the confiscation of all his properties and assets.
There have also been the trials of Jewish prisoners who have received similar fates for very similar reasons. Obviously none of these imprisonments are justified, and action needs to be taken to ensure that these people are released as quickly as possible. I urge Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran. The Australian government must continue to take every opportunity in both multilateral forums and its bilateral relationships to promote the universality and indivisibility of all human rights, specifically the right to freedom of religion and belief. I thank the Baha'is community for their assistance in preparing today's presentation. 
 (Mr Nehl)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

name: Thomson, Andrew, MP
text:
—I think this is a very interesting motion because it deals with issues that are pertinent to Australia's national interest. The position of Iran in the politics of the Middle East is significant and changes to the standards of human rights covenants within that country will have an effect on countries around Iran. Some of the things that we ought to take note of include some improvement in human rights standards in Iran, as acknowledged in the first part of the motion. Later clauses deal with some of the more unfortunate things that are still going on. Of particular interest to me is the treatment of 13 members of the Jewish community who were charged with various offences, 10 of whom are currently in prison, facing charges of espionage and so forth.
What underlies some of the changes in Iran are some changes in its demographic trends. In 1996, Iran held a census and found that 40 per cent of the population was aged under 14 years. So now, with a few years passing, these citizens, who are approaching their twenties, perhaps represent Iran's best hope for the creation of a modern democracy in the country. It is important to emphasise, too, that, although the reforms are only in their embryonic stage and they still have much to achieve, there has been some noteworthy groundwork set down by President Khatami, who is described as a moderate and who was elected to office in 1997 with a groundswell of support from the voting public. He has made some progress in trying to remake what was an intensely theocratic state and to turn it into a much less restrictive one. This is why, with the support of a young population he is achieving some success. 
There has been some degree of cultural liberalisation. The government in Iran now recognises marriages between members of the Baha'i community, and it is proposed that university places will soon be open to members of this minority group. Although that is a positive step forward, it is astonishing how intensely discriminated against this community has been in Iran. You cannot erase that over the course of just a few months. I do not know quite why the government of Iran has such an intense hatred of this minority group. They seem a very peaceful folk to me, but it has been the case. Although there has been some liberalisation in the treatment of these people, it behoves us, the Australian government—as the motion and its mover, the member for Swan, say—to continue to scrutinise very carefully what is going on there and to speak up when the need arises.
President Khatami has also indicated his commitment to human rights in a more general sense and to creating a more open dialogue between nations. This is a very welcome movement in Iran because, compared with some of its neighbours—for instance, Afghanistan, where the ultraorthodox Islamic militia, the Taliban, hold government—Iran's human rights record is marginally more favourable. Next door in Iraq there are significant problems with Saddam Hussein still holding office, but, in the long term, Iran could have a democratising effect on some of its neighbours. Australia would welcome the opportunity to improve relations with countries in the Middle East generally, were this process to take place.
However, in spite of some of these reforms, there is obviously still within Iran an ongoing tension between reformists and very hardline elements—those who are stalwart defenders of the revolution that still maintains a stranglehold on some of Iran's institutions. It remains very much under the control of its clerics, who maintain control over the armed forces, the broadcasting authorities, the judiciary and so forth. So there is a conflict between these two groups: the clerics on one side and the parliament, or Majlis, on the other. This conflict is having an impact on the efforts of the president and the new parliament to effect democratisation that the majority of Iranians appear to support.
We have to encourage reform, but, at the same time, we must not be blind to the existing and continuing abuses. The most immediate human rights concern is the fate of what is called the `Shiraz 10'. These are Iranian Jews charged with espionage, and they are conspicuous victims of this bitter struggle between the reformist and the hardliners within Iran. Australia has acknowledged its concern for the safety of these people, who were arrested and imprisoned in the city of Shiraz, and we continue to argue for their release. The Iranian government's actions in targeting, arresting, incarcerating and, thereafter, trying and sentencing these Jews represent a significant blow to their internal reform processes, and to do something about it would serve Iran's reputation very well.
More alarming I suppose is the fact that the trials of these innocent people reveal an absence of democratic rights and due process for minority religious groups in Iran. Since their incarceration, Australia has made 27 separate representations to the Iranian government expressing concern about the fate of these people. In July this year 10 of the 13 people charged in Shiraz were found guilty and given sentences of between four and 13 years. These people included community leaders, religious teachers and a rabbi, and initial concern for the welfare of those convicted extends both to their immediate physical safety and to that of their families. Subsequent appeals have resulted in sentence reductions of two to six years for some people—indeed, for six out of the 10. While I suppose this is something of a demonstration of good faith, it is more appropriate that those convictions be overturned.
In a larger sense, this issue throws light on Iran's treatment of Jewish people in prison. It highlights the general issue of human rights standards and the problem of how we go about encouraging countries to meet those standards. Originally, the most basic principle of the law of nations—or international law, as it is called these days—was that one nation would not interfere in the internal affairs of another. This enabled sovereign nations to navigate their way through trying to resolve world problems that cropped up from time to time without too much conflict. We dealt with each other nation to nation and did not interfere constantly in what was happening in a neighbour's territory.  
However, particularly postwar, some of the conventions and agreements that established universal standards of human rights have sought to vary this basic notion—by declaring that such-and-such a manner of treating somebody shall be a violation of a basic human right, for example. That gives rise to the presumption that it is all right to interfere to some degree, or threaten to interfere, in the internal affairs of another country. The trouble is that, by setting these standards and then cloaking them in the costume of law without providing for an enforcement mechanism, we create endless frustration. On one side, we have these standards that must be met; and, on the other side, we have no real way of making sure that they are met—as we would be able to do in a domestic situation.
In the end, peer nations—such as is happening at the moment in this parliament—put pressure on another government to deal with its people, albeit religious minorities, in a more gentle and civil way. That is the only practical way of improving human rights, and it can be a good approach if we persist. However, we do not need so-called leadership from Euro politicians, appointed with grand titles, from the UN system telling us what we should or should not protest about. These are the sorts of things that sovereign nations and the elected members of parliaments in those nations can decide very well for themselves. That is exactly what we are doing in the case of those people who are suffering oppression within Iran.

name: Hoare, Kelly, MP
text:
—In seconding this motion, I congratulate my colleague the member for Swan on keeping the plight of the Baha'is in Iran in the public arena. I will give members a short history of the Baha'i faith. The Baha'i faith was founded in Iran in the mid-1880s and Baha'is have been persecuted there ever since. By religious standards, the faith is relatively new. The Baha'i understand that this type of persecution stems from the fact that their faith is new and that the traditionalist, or older faiths, misunderstand or fear a new religion. 
However, this understanding does not provide acceptance of the fact that, during the 19th century, 20,000 people died as a result of violence perpetrated on Baha'i followers by the Islamic religious authorities. That persecution and violence continued into the 20th century, with regular violence being experienced by the Baha'is in Iran. Different regimes over the years have even formalised policies of oppression against the Baha'is as concessions to the clergy and to garner support from the nation's Islamic leadership. During these years Baha'i literature was banned, Baha'i marriages were not recognised, Baha'is in the public service were demoted or sacked and Baha'i schools were even closed.
Another massive round of violence—murders, rapes and robberies—occurred following the decision of the Pahlavi regime in 1955 to allow Islamic clerics to broadcast on national radio denouncing the Baha'i faith, thus inciting further violence. The irony of the suffering of the Baha'i followers in Iran is that a major tenet of their faith is that loyalty to government is an essential spiritual and social principle. Even today, as Baha'i followers continue to face persecution in Iran, the faith pronounces loyalty to governments.
This motion also urges Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran. In this regard, particular importance is placed on the biannual resolution of the human rights situation in Iran at the United Nations General Assembly and the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. This resolution expresses international concern about a range of serious human rights violations occurring in Iran and provides recommendations to Iran to remedy these violations. The resolution has been of critical importance in discouraging even greater violations of the rights of the Baha'is by extremist elements in Iran. However, rather than addressing the United Nations recommendations for protecting the rights of Iranian citizens, the Iranian government has devoted its energies to defeating the resolution. 
Successive Australian governments have consistently supported the resolution and Australia has been a co-sponsor of the resolutions since their inception in 1980. Given the wide range of human rights abuses in Iran detailed in numerous United Nations reports, there is no justification for any change in Australia's policy. Therefore, I am happy to congratulate the government on its decision to co-sponsor this year's resolution that is now before the United Nations General Assembly. I call on the government to continue this bipartisan tradition of defending the human rights and religious freedom of the Baha'is and other religious minorities in Iran—particularly in light of the report on this important topic that was presented just last week by this parliament's human rights subcommittee. It recommended that:
... the Australian Government continue to take every opportunity, in both multilateral forums and in its bilateral relationships, to promote the universality and indivisability of all human rights, specifically the right to freedom of religion and belief. 
Co-sponsorship of the UN resolution on the human rights situation in Iran presents such an opportunity. Moreover, in light of this recommendation, I call on the Australian government to give priority to working with like-minded nations to ensure greater international support for the resolution of the human rights situation in Iran. Two decades is enough time for Iran to remedy this human rights issue, which justifiably continues to concern this parliament and the international community. I acknowledge my good friend Tom Jones, Secretary of the Newcastle Baha'is, for his continued support and friendship and for his ongoing local advocacy of world peace and international harmony.

name: Southcott, Dr Andrew, MP
text:
—In responding to this motion from the member for Swan, I would like to first talk about the political situation in Iran, the encouraging things that we can say about Iran, and then focus on the treatment of the Baha'i community and the Jewish community in Iran. At the February 2000 elections for the Iranian parliament, President Khatami received the support of the Iranian people. The encouraging things about this occurrence are that President Khatami has a reformist program and he has emphasised the promotion of the rule of law, upholding the Iranian constitution.
Iran's human rights record does compare favourably to those of some of its neighbours. As for improvements that we have seen, there has been greater government transparency; there has been increased women's access to education and to politics; and legislation covering reform of the marriage laws has been introduced into the parliament. A judicial reform has been canvassed but has not gone any further than that. Despite those things, which are on the good side of the ledger, we should be concerned about how minority groups, especially Jews and Baha'is, are being treated in Iran. I am pleased that the Australian government has sought assurances that minorities are protected by the constitution.
The Baha'i community of South Australia has its headquarters in my electorate. I was pleased recently to attend an evening its members organised, which celebrated the year 2000 as the International Year of Peace. I am also pleased that the foreign affairs minister, Alexander Downer, raised human rights issues, including the discrimination against the Baha'i community in Iran, during his July 2000 visit to Teheran. Australia has also co-sponsored the resolutions relating to human rights in Iran, both at the United Nations General Assembly just recently and also at the Commission of Human Rights. Australia has made representations on individual cases and for the Baha'i community as a whole in Canberra and Teheran. So we are continuing to make representations about this important minority, whose members have been persecuted in Iran. 
In regard to the Jewish community, Australia has made 27 separate representations to the Iranian government in concern over the arrest and trial of 13 Iranian Jews and nine Muslims. I think, since this motion was put in, three members of the Jewish community have been acquitted, so it is now actually 10 members of the Jewish community. Thirteen of these representations to Iran have been made at a ministerial level. Australia has expressed concerns at the trial outcome for these 13 Iranian Jews and also at deficiencies in the trial process—and it will continue to make those representations.
In summary, some improvements are being made in Iran. We need to continue through motions like this, which are helpful, to co-sponsor the human rights motions in the United Nations General Assembly and also the Commission of Human Rights. We should also be prepared to take up individual cases, as we have done and which have been taken up at a ministerial level.
—The time allotted for the debate has not quite expired, but I think it would probably be in keeping with what the member for Swan had in mind if, in fact, we were to adjourn the debate.

name: Mossfield, Frank, MP
text:
—I draw to the attention of this parliament a serious issue relating to a constituent of Greenway, Mr Keith Harrison. He served in the Australian Navy on the HMAS Hawkesbury during the atomic tests at Monte Bello. Keith is now suffering from leukemia but is unable to get any preferential medical treatment or a service pension, as he is not considered a `veteran' under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The HMAS Hawkesbury was the only naval ship to remain in the atomic testing area for the duration of the testing period, except for a short trip back to Fremantle. When the Hawkesbury did dock in Fremantle during the testing period, there was considerable public concern about radiation contamination.
Although Keith served a total of six years in the Navy, he is one of only three crewmen of the Hawkesbury who did not serve in an operational area during `specified dates'. Therefore, he is classified as an `ex-serviceman' and not a `veteran'. It is my view that a strong moral case exists for Keith to be considered a victim of the atomic tests at Monte Bello. I will be asking the various government departments to acknowledge this fact and grant Keith the necessary means to obtain medical treatment for any illness contracted during his service in the Australian Navy.

name: Pyne, Chris, MP
Danby, Michael, MP
text:
—I second the motion. How far we seem from those days when Mr Rabin, the late Prime Minister of Israel, shook hands with his long-time adversary, Mr Yasser Arafat, the President of the Palestinian National Authority in the rose garden at the White House, Washington. The last few weeks are tragic for all those around the world who follow events in that part of the world where our civilisations began. The current situation is that we have, apparently, the two sides as intractably apart as ever before. At the end of the Cold War we saw an apparent solution to the problems in South Africa and Ireland, and lots of people around the world were very pleased to observe that the Middle East seemed to be part of this process where Cold War tensions no longer heightened the conflicts in those parts of the world where conflict was very high. 
The recent historical background to the last few weeks is, I think, worth examining. The current Israeli government is a Labour government led by Mr Ehud Barak. Mr Barak in his election program proposed and promised a number of radical measures for achieving peace. One of them was the unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon that was completed about halfway through this year. That withdrawal was designed to solve the problem of the people in south Lebanon and northern Israel being involved in constant conflict. That was achieved—not with the greatest of grace, but it did happen. One of Mr Barak's chess pieces was moved in the direction of peace. 
The second offer came with negotiations that American President Clinton had with the then and now the late President of Syria, Hafez al-Assad. Those negotiations arose following the election of the Barak government and were designed to see a withdrawal of the Israelis from the entire Golan Heights. I might say that many Australian parliamentarians who visited that area over the decades since it was the scene of conflict in the 1973 war and the 1967 war remarked on the generosity—some people would say the wisdom—of Mr Barak in making that offer. It was an offer which anyone who has stood in the very small spaces we are talking about and looked down into the valley of Galilee below understands is a big risk for peace. That was the second chess peace that was offered but was unfortunately not pursued by Mr Assad. 
The next and most important part of this saga was referred to by the member for Sturt. That was the offer in those long days of negotiation between Mr Arafat and Prime Minister Barak at the American President's retreat at Camp David. The extent of that offer, to people who follow in detail the Middle East, was very surprising. As the member for Sturt said, it involved an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel, 95 per cent of the territories, all of Arab East Jerusalem, shared sovereignty over the holy sites in Jerusalem, and an exchange of territory for the remaining five, six or seven per cent between Israel proper and those heavily populated areas of the West Bank that were contiguous with Israel but were heavily populated by Israeli Jews.
I note, by the way, that the Israeli Arabs, who are proposed to be part of this exchange of territory, are not very happy with this idea. Despite their support for the Palestinian Arabs and their concerns about the violence in the territories and the deaths in the recent conflict, they are not enamoured of the idea of being part of any population or land transfer.
Mr Arafat, for reasons that are best understood by him, did not accept this most comprehensive offer ever made. If this House, as a responsible House, is seeking to add to the responsible discussion of this troubled part of the world in seeking political solutions, it ought to focus on the kinds of political solutions that it might help bring about. The American President, who presided over these discussions, Mr Clinton, was very disappointed. The Chairman of the Palestinian Authority, Mr Arafat, proceeded on an international visit where, to his surprise, the leaders of both France and Russia—traditionally supporters of the Palestinians—informed him that the Palestinians should accept the deal and that they would not support a unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state, the alternative for which Mr Arafat was hoping to get their support.
Very interestingly for me, the Labor Party national conference took place around this time, and those participating in the Labor Party conference—who have previously held different points of view on the Middle East—took a unanimous view and did not support unilateral declarations. We supported negotiation through peaceful discussions between the parties. Since those attempts at getting international support for a unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state, there has been an awful mess—the death of many innocent people on both sides in past months. Like any human, when I saw the picture of the boy who was shot at the Netzarim crossroads, my emotions were stirred. The shooting was a tragedy. That children are being involved in this kind of conflict is something all of us regret. I later saw an aerial photograph of crossfire taking place between a Palestinian police station and an Israeli strong point. This fact is neither here nor there: the tragedy of the boy is not relieved by the circumstances in which he died. 
As responsible friends of both peoples in the area—and Australia has a very honourable record in helping to achieve a just and peaceful solution to the conflict over there—we ought to be focusing on the political solutions to this conflict. Any examination of the peace plan as advanced by Camp David ought to lead this House to supporting it, as the motion moved by the member for Sturt outlines. It is regrettable that, in the last few days, the Palestinian Legislative Council has voted for a continuation of the intifada, or the uprising or violence in the territories. A slightly encouraging aspect is that it has also voted for the continuation of negotiations. I do not think both can occur at the same time. I hope Mr Barak's gamble on calling early elections will be supported by the Israeli population. He has offered about as much as I think any Israeli leader has ever offered in the past or will offer. I hope that the measures that he has taken to resume negotiations with the Palestinians bear fruit and that the Israeli population, in an election, support those peace moves. It is in the hands of the people who live in the area, through peaceful negotiations.

name: Georgiou, Petro, MP
text:
—I wish to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Sturt. In the last few months, we have witnessed an outbreak of violence in the Middle East. This violence has led to the death and injury of many innocent Palestinian and Israeli men, women and children. The loss and suffering of both sides in this conflict is deeply felt by this parliament. The tragedy is compounded by the fact that the Middle East peace process seems to have all but collapsed. The diplomatic triumph that brought with it great hope and potential reward today lies all but abandoned.
Since his election victory last year, Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, has dedicated his administration to securing peace for Israel. In the last year, the government of Israel has withdrawn Israeli forces from Lebanon and has offered Syria a peace proposal that included all of the Golan Heights. To the Palestinians, the Israeli government offered a peace settlement at Camp David that was both generous and brave. A fortnight ago, our Prime Minister, during his address to the annual dinner of the Australia/Israel and Jewish Affairs Council expressed the Australian government's view on that peace proposal when he said:
I do not believe that any Prime Minister of Israel could have offered more than did Ehud Barak at Camp David. It was an offer that should have been accepted and it is tragic in the extreme that it has not been accepted.
Since the Palestinian Authority's refusal of Israel's offer, we have watched as talk of peace by Yasser Arafat and other Palestinian leaders has been replaced by the rhetoric of violence and conflict. When the peace process commenced in 1993, the Chairman of the PLO renounced violence. At that time, he stated:
... the PLO renounces the use of terrorism and other acts of violence, and will assume responsibility over all PLO elements and personnel in order to assure their compliance.
In recent months, despite repeated requests and calls from the international community and Israel, the Palestinian leadership has done little to call for an end to violence. It is also disturbing that Yasser Arafat chose to release from jail many known terrorists from various extremist organisations. As a consequence, we are now witnessing the return of terrorist bombings of buses and public places in Israel and an escalation of civilian deaths.
The Palestinian people have a legitimate aspiration to realise their own state. We recognise and support that aspiration. But the most effective vehicle to deliver that outcome is the peace process. Since the signing of the Declaration of Principles, the peace process has brought the Palestinian people closer to nationhood and delivered more tangible benefits than at any time in the last half century. Today, more than 97 per cent of the Palestinian population live under Palestinian rule. The Palestinian Authority controls more than 40 per cent of the West Bank and Gaza. Since the Oslo agreement, the Palestinian people have also been the recipients of huge capital inflows and aid contributions from the international community. 
Australia is a strong friend and a staunch ally of the state of Israel and the people of Israel. There are few nations in the world which have overcome so much, fought so hard and sacrificed so many of their sons and daughters in the search for peace. Five million people in a sliver of land that would fit into Victoria 10 times continue to live with the daily reality that they face hostile neighbours still intent on their destruction. Yet, in a nation where every square mile carries with it serious strategic consequences, Israel continues to propose peace initiatives and concessions that increase her strategic vulnerability. I think we can all appreciate the frustration felt by many in Israel that, after having taken great risks in the search for peace, they are today faced with the same insecurity and violence that beset their nation before the peace process commenced. As Israel goes to the polls in a new election, it is my hope that, despite the current climate, her people continue to search for a renewed path to peace. I commend the motion to the House.

name: Ripoll, Bernie, MP
text:
—In speaking in support of the member for Sturt's motion, I join my colleague the member for Melbourne Ports and other members in supporting peaceful negotiation rather than force or violence as a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Australian Labor Party has a long and honourable record of supporting both Arab and Jewish rights in that part of the world. Australia was involved in the original decision to partition Palestine into an Arab-Palestinian state and the Jewish state of Israel. That fair partitioning is the underlying basis for this motion. Dr Evatt, as chairman of the UN General Assembly, saw the partition of Palestine, which was and is the wise and right manner in which this matter should be and might be resolved. Like King Solomon, we have to support the parties who are willing to make a political compromise, not the party that wants to have everything.
At our ALP national conference, we called on all parties to not make unilateral declarations that would pre-empt negotiation. Peace can come only as a result of negotiation between the parties, not from us. Mr Arafat was told the same by the governments of Russia and France, which have been traditional supporters of the Palestinian cause. It is obvious that this is an emotional topic, with children being captured on television dying in crossfire. We also see mobs desecrating religious sites and lynching individuals. In Australia, we should be contributing to a political solution, not to emotional appeals on one side or the other.
In my contribution, I do not really want to talk about who is right and who is wrong, because in these matters that is a fine line to distinguish. I do want to pick up on a point about the media and about the citing of individual cases. The media has portrayed at times very graphic sights and has, I believe, with those images taken one side or the other and sometimes both. I do not believe that these grim pictures and people witnessing these events actually help the cause; rather, they destroy the negotiations and the potential for peace. In the very recent past, we have seen people like President Clinton with Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat having discussions, having negotiations and genuinely working towards what might be a peaceful solution in the Middle East.
The battle between the Israelis and the Palestinians has been going on for many years, and it is one that obviously does not have an easy solution and cannot be easily resolved by combined negotiations, but I think negotiations are the only way that it can be resolved. At some point, both sides must sit down and both sides must give and take. There was just recently some of that giving and some of that taking, and I think Ehud Barak has made some generous concessions in working towards what might be a solution. At the end of the day, the negotiations will have to come to the point where they actually find what will be the area of Palestine or a Palestinian state. As the member for Kooyong rightly pointed out, the Palestians do deserve their own state, they do deserve to have their own territory and they do deserve to be the masters of their own destiny. At some stage, the two must come together to find where that point is. 
I will quickly refer to point 3 of the motion moved by the member for Sturt. It `calls on all partners to resume negotiations without the threat of violence and without the premature announcement of unilateral declarations'. For these negotiations to continue, they must continue in peace. Violence must end. Violence is not benefiting one side or the other; it is only ensuring more graphic pictures in the media. I would also like to highlight point 5 of the motion, which says the House `hopes that the conflict will be resolved in the framework of agreement and compromise'. I would also like to highlight point 7, which `calls on all countries surrounding the conflict between Israel and the Palestinian territories to ensure their sovereign territory not be used to promote aggression'. Other countries should not contribute to the violence and the current problems in the Middle East.
There is one good thing we are doing through this parliament, and that is the Australia-Israel Friendship Group. It is a good group chaired by the member for Sturt and deputy chaired by the member for Melbourne Ports. I am a member of that friendship group and am glad to be. I fully support the good work being done here in support of the peace negotiations and in support of both sides finding a resolution. All we can do in this place is lend our support and offer any advice and assistance that we can to both parties and hope that, in the very near future, a solution is found and peace is brought to the Middle East.
 (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

name: Plibersek, Tanya, MP
text:
—We have heard recently about many rural and regional communities complaining that services have been taken from their local communities, and that it has had a consequent effect on the standard of living of those people in those communities. This is true not only of regional and rural communities, however. In my electorate, which is a metropolitan electorate, the withdrawal of banking services from a number of suburbs has had a very detrimental effect on the people whom I represent. There has been round after round of branch closures in my electorate. Of course, with those branch closures come staff losses. But with those branch closures also comes rising inconvenience for the people who have relied on those banks until now. The exorbitant fees and charges that many of the banks have been charging, particularly people with low account balances, have had a very detrimental effect on my constituents.
The Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman received 22 per cent more complaints in 1999-2000 than in the previous year. This is just a small indication of the frustration that many ordinary Australians are feeling on this issue. The Prime Minister is said to be a supporter of battlers; he calls himself a supporter of battlers in Australia. Yet his inaction on the issue of banks and the fees and charges that they are levelling on my constituents, and the fact that he has taken no clear line on the number of bank closures, would suggest that he is a bit more interested in the large donations that the big banks make to the coalition parties. 
—And the Labor Party.
—They make much bigger donations to the coalition parties—vastly bigger.
—Prove that.
—It is very easy to prove it, in fact, if you have been putting your returns in properly. Between 1993 and 1999, Australia's big four banks—Westpac, the National Australia Bank, ANZ and the Commonwealth—have closed a quarter of their branches nationally. Over the same period, the combined net profits of the big four nearly tripled. In the first six months of this year alone some 355 bank branches closed across the country—that is a rate of about two branch closures almost every day of the year. The Finance Sector Union is very upset about the branch closures.  
In my electorate of Sydney, the Commonwealth Bank has recently closed branches in Waterloo, Alexandria and Erskineville. Last month I was informed that the bank would be closing yet another branch in my electorate, at Railway Square. That is due to close just three weeks before Christmas. On Friday I received another notice from the Commonwealth Bank that it is about to close another branch in my electorate. This one is on one of Sydney's busiest streets: Oxford Street. It is very difficult to argue that they are closing because they do not have customers. In fact, I know that they are overwhelmed with customers. The Commonwealth Bank has closed over 75 branches in the first half of this year alone, or 680 branches since 1993—more than any other bank. Westpac, however, has also been closing branches in my electorate. Recently, they have closed branches at Waterloo, Camperdown and in the southern part of the central business district. 
Moving on to fees and charges, in 1999 fees and commissions charged by the banks increased by $1.32 billion. The recent Reserve Bank and ACCC report entitled Debit and credit card schemes in Australia: a study of interchange fees and access demonstrates clearly that the banks are profiteering on fees and charges. Interchange fees—imposed when a consumer withdraws money from their bank at another bank's automatic teller machine—are around double the average cost of providing these services. Similarly, issuing credit cards creates revenue well above the average cost of providing these services. One week after the release of the report, the banks announced plans to raise fees and charges by as much as 50 per cent, and to introduce new charges where there were none before. These increases saw the Commonwealth Bank increase fees for over-the-counter transactions from $2 to $3 and giroPost transactions from $2 to $3. The National Australia Bank announced an increase in the fee for over-the-counter transactions from $2 to $3 as well, at the same time announcing that it would close 100 branches in metropolitan areas. Likewise, Westpac increased its over-the-counter fees from $2 to $2.50.
These charges make a significant impact on the lives of pensioners and people on low incomes, for whom every dollar must count—especially after the introduction of the GST, which has hit these vulnerable people particularly hard. The majority of the 6,199 cases put to the banking ombudsman related to complaints by consumers that their bank had charged fees and charges contrary to the terms and conditions of that account. The problem with this, of course, is that consumers must be eternally vigilant to make sure that their banks are not, in fact, charging fees contrary to the terms of their account. But it puts a vast onus on pretty vulnerable consumers to take on large financial institutions.
In respect of jobs, since 1993 the number of employees at the big four banks fell by over 21,000 people, and the rate of profit made by the banks per employee has increased. However, workers and the Finance Sector Union have had to fight a protracted campaign for even the most basic wage rise. In 1998, it was reported that the head of Australia's biggest bank—Mr Don Argus of the National Australia Bank—was calculated to have been paid some 103 times the wage of a first-year teller. The closure of bank branches not only affects the staff of the bank itself, it has a dramatic impact on the community surrounding the bank and particularly on the shopping centres that surround banks in suburban shopping strips. There can be up to a 40 per cent downturn in retail trade in those suburban shopping centres when a branch closes.
There is a particularly stark illustration of this in my own electorate, in Waterloo. As I said, it has lost two banks recently and a post office. Suburbs like Waterloo are almost becoming ghost suburbs, as people have to leave the area to do all of their shopping and all of their banking and postal transactions. Elderly people and people with mobility difficulties in particular are disadvantaged by fewer branches, higher fees and charges and a reduction in face-to-face services. Closing a bank branch means that pensioners have to spend part of their precious pension money on actually getting to a bank in a neighbouring suburb. 
One of the problems in my electorate is that there is quite a high number of bag snatchers in the inner city. Pensioners are forced to travel from Waterloo to Redfern, for example, to access their pension payments. If they want to do that only once a week or once a fortnight, they must carry quite large amounts of money—perhaps their entire pension. Unfortunately, the bag snatchers in the area know when it is pension day and many older people are attacked for their pension money because they have to carry it quite long distances as bank branches closer to home have closed.
It is easy to identify problems, but I think it is incumbent upon us to start discussing solutions. The banks have spent an enormous amount of money on advertising and I remind honourable members of the cash for comment scandal. These are not solutions to the problem of the poor standing of banks in the community. If banks are to improve their relationship with consumers and the community, they must start providing a better service—particularly for those on low incomes with low account balances. Banks have an obligation to society as well as to their shareholders, and people on low incomes cannot be excluded from financial services simply because their business may not create as much profit for the banks as do wealthy people and wealthy corporations.
With the top four banks enjoying more than 80 per cent of the banking market and making a combined total of $9 billion between them, the `leave it to the market' answer is clearly unworkable. The government must direct the ACCC to continue to monitor bank fees and charges. We also have to bring the banks to the negotiating table with consumer groups and pensioner groups to create a social charter for banks. A social charter is important in ensuring that every Australian can access simple banking services. The social charter must be binding, otherwise it will be just a toothless tiger. It should include a requirement to provide a fee-free account for pensioners and social security recipients. We must also address the problem of banks that have closed branches thus making it impossible for their customers to access local branches or even ATMs.

name: Ronaldson, Michael, MP
text:
—I say at the outset of my speech on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000 that I will limit my time today because, unfortunately, as a result of the opposition's actions last Thursday, a considerable amount of debating time for this important bill was lost. So given the time constraints and the need to get this bill into the Senate for their consideration and to get the money out on to local roads, I will keep my comments very short. I received a letter on 29 November, which stated:
Dear Michael,
LOCAL ROADS FUNDING BOOST
Hepburn Shire Council thanks you and the Federal Government for the very positive funding boost for local roads. 
As you are aware we and other Councils have not had the resources to adequately maintain the extensive local road network. Your sympathy and support on this issue over recent years is very much appreciated. 
We will ensure that this funding is used effectively and strategically. Council already has detailed lists with priority assessment. We expect that much of the funding will be channelled into resealing of local roads and gravel re-sheets of unsealed roads. This would provide more extensive benefits than concentrating the funding in a small number of projects. 
The problems with infrastructure require long-term solutions. Our community has recognised that ongoing rate increases will be needed together with improved Federal and State funding. We request that this four year funding program be progressively assessed for effectiveness and benefits with a view to becoming ongoing.
Thank you once again Michael, for your support.
The letter is signed by Victor Szwed, Chief Executive Officer, and Max O'Shea, the Mayor of Hepburn Shire Council. An article in the Ballarat Courier last week quoted City of Ballarat Mayor, John Barnes, following the federal government's announcement of the Roads to Recovery Program. Councillor Barnes was quoted as saying:
“I think it's very generous”, he said.
“We're very happy about it.”
The Mayor of Hepburn Shire Council, Max O'Shea, was again quoted as saying that the funding was a `wonderful boost for local roads'. The Moorabool Shire will be receiving some $3.279 million over the four-year period. The article stated:
Chief executive officer Chris Gillard said the funding would contribute to closing the council infrastructure funding gap. 
“It will mean some projects will be able to be brought forward,”
In the Ballarat Courier again—it is a marvellous newspaper that covers a broad range of interests to my community—the `Farmers' Weekly' section stated:
Victorian Farmers Federation president Peter Walsh said the increase represented about a 75 per cent increase in the annual funding for local roads.  
“The deterioration in local roads is a major constraint on growth in rural Australia,” Mr Walsh said. 
The Commonwealth has called upon the states to also increase funding for local roads. The VFF endorses this call for the Victorian Government to increase its allocation to rural local roads. 
“The Labor Party made an undertaking prior to the last election to `commit resources to rural local roads' but so far this commitment has not been met.
The state government did make that comment prior to the last election, but since then any requests for an increase in local road funding has fallen on deaf ears. It is my understanding that the Victorian transport minister, Peter Batchelor—and this is from a press release by Minister Anderson—is quoted as saying `local roads are the responsibility of local governments'. 
The simple fact is that we—and I am sure honourable members on the other side do likewise and if they do not they are not doing their job properly—speak to our local government representatives to ascertain from them what the real issues are. I hit the circuit about 12 months ago to speak to all my mayors, shire CEOs and shire presidents, again, to ascertain what their needs were, and the single biggest issue was local roads. It was local roads—tens the field after that. It was the only issue confronting my local government representatives—it was not the only issue, but it was the key issue that they wanted addressed. This is a very significant contribution to infrastructure in rural and regional Australia. This is a very significant contribution to local road infrastructure in my electorate of Ballarat and the general region. In the wider region, some $25 million has gone into local roads.
There will be some, I suspect, who, through ignorance—and I do not say that in a negative sense—would not understand the importance of local roads to not only rural and regional economies but also national economies. There are 1.7 million Australians who depend on the export industry for their jobs—that is one in four people in rural and regional Australia. These jobs are primarily generated from produce that begins its journey on local roads. I was speaking to a constituent on Saturday night who advised me that a road near him carries a school bus and he got one of the children to hop out of the bus the other day and step into a pothole on this road and he could not see anything six inches below this child's knee. This is a local road that is taking school children to school. This is a local road—and I am sure the honourable member for Corangamite, who is sitting beside me, will be acutely of aware of this—that is not only transporting children but also transporting families and transporting agricultural produce. This is the lifeblood of rural communities—the lifeblood—and they have been starved of funds. 
In 1991, all three tiers of government got their heads together and said that federal government would fund national highways, state governments would fund state roads and local government would fund local roads. The simple fact is that that agreement has not worked. That agreement has seen an extraordinary deterioration in local road infrastructure throughout rural and regional Australia. It is a significant matter for all Australians because all Australians have both an economic and a social investment in local roads. They may well be 2,500 kilometres away from where people live, but we all have an investment in local roads. They are pivotal to this country's economy. They are the lifeblood socially and economically of rural and regional communities, and the state of deterioration is absolutely appalling. In fact, I would go so far as to say that it is a matter of national shame that our local road network has got to this stage. Local government, as hard as it tried, simply could not spend the money that was required. That is why the federal government, in consultation with local government, has given a $1.2 billion boost over four years to local roads.
Members of parliament get phone calls about many things: some not so complimentary, some complimentary. My phones have been ringing off the hook in relation to this with people desperately urging me to get their local roads fixed. I have told those people that we are directing the money straight into local government, so that local government can determine their priorities. If you look at people like those in the Shire of Hepburn, they have already done that work. They know where the money is to be spent. They know it is desperately needed and they know it will be money very well spent. 
I think this is one of the greatest achievements of this government because it addresses everything across the board. It is a national program with national benefits. I say to those people who are waiting for their local roads to be fixed: this is a partnership. It is a $1.2 billion partnership from the federal government; local government is making its contribution; and I call upon the states to match this funding, because they have as much investment in local roads as local government does and as the federal government does. I urge them, I plead with them, to please match this funding so that we can make a significant difference to what I think is a national issue. Given the time constraints and the number of my colleagues who wish to speak on this bill, I draw my comments to a close.

name: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP
text:
—I will attempt to follow the honourable member for Ballarat's lead in keeping my comments short to ensure that all members of this House have an opportunity to speak on what is a very important bill, but I will have some difficulty in following his rhetoric because my views differ somewhat from those of the member for Ballarat with respect to the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000. This bill is about a broken promise. The Prime Minister gave an ironclad guarantee prior to the last election that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise, and it was a promise that he reaffirmed after the election. This bill is the second of the government's political responses to the fallout it is encountering as a result of that broken election promise.
It is a serious broken election promise and one that affects all people from all walks of life. As many members would be aware, over the last few weeks I have been participating in the federal opposition's fuel inquiry. It is an inquiry that is designed to establish the extent of the Prime Minister's GST induced fuel tax windfall and how best that can be returned to the Australian people. It has been a very interesting exercise because, wherever we go, particularly in regional Australia, we are overwhelmed with people who are keen to share their petrol experiences with us. Not only individuals, families and small business operators but also, indeed, a number of community groups ranging from Meals on Wheels through to community transport are keen to share their story with us, keen to let us know how John Howard's broken election promise is affecting them.
We have had local government bodies before us, as well. The member for Ballarat spent a fair bit of time sharing with us how happy local government is about the Roads to Recovery Program. Many of those local government representatives are with us in the building tonight and we welcome them. We are hearing a different story at the petrol inquiry. We are hearing numerous stories about the manner in which higher fuel prices are affecting the operations of local government. For example, council bodies that have fixed contracts for work they do for state roads bodies are not compensated in terms of those contracts for increases in fuel prices.
So there is a mixed message out there. In particular, owner-driver truckies have approached our inquiry in great numbers, explaining how they are being squeezed at both ends and how they are being asked to pass on fictional embedded wholesale sales tax savings and, at the same time, bear the brunt of higher fuel prices. This is an issue hurting people badly in the regions in particular. It is going to get worse.
—I rise on a point of order, Deputy Madam Speaker. The member for Hunter has been going for four minutes now and has made no reference to the bill at all, let alone its context. I ask that you bring him back to the subject matter of the bill.
—As I listened to the Chief Government Whip, I am listening to the member for Hunter. There is no point of order. 
—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will make sure that I get my 20 minutes now. I thank the member for Ballarat. As I was pointing out, this is the government's political response to its failure to keep its election promise on fuel prices. I was about to say before I was rudely interrupted by the Chief Government Whip that the situation for the government is about to get worse. I heard the AAA—the Australian Automobile Association—talking this morning about the prospect, due to maybe an easing in the price of world oil, of petrol prices coming down a bit.
I beg to differ for one particular reason. No-one has considered this yet, but we all know that each year during the Christmas period the major oil companies take the opportunity to exploit the sudden increase in demand for petrol. They exploit the desire of families to travel on holiday. Every year it is the same: surprise, surprise, the price of petrol goes up by between 5c and 10c in late December. There is no solid reason or real explanation for this other than the fact that the major oil companies seize the opportunity to take excessive profits throughout the Christmas period when they know that demand is high and that the purchase of fuel is essential if Australian families want to holiday by car.
Let us consider what will happen this year. When the major oil companies force up petrol prices by five per cent in their attempt to take excessive profits by exploiting the Christmas holiday period, what will happen to the GST? It will also increase. This year there will be a compound effect. We have experienced higher petrol prices throughout the Christmas period for decades, but, because the GST is an ad valorem tax, the situation will be compounded this year. Ten per cent on 95c is less than 10 per cent on one dollar. The government need not kid itself that the political pressure is about to ease; I believe it is about to get even tougher. 
What was the government's first reaction to its failed election promise? Its first response was the so-called Fuel Sales Grants Scheme designed to ensure that motorists in rural and regional Australia received a rebate of between 1c and 2c. It was a desperate attempt by the government to deliver on its pre-election GST petrol promise, but that initiative has failed. Throughout the short history of this scheme, a number of anomalies have indicated that it is flawed. The first triggered an ACCC inquiry—the results of which are still pending—into suggestions that the fuel grants scheme is not being passed on to those for whom it is intended—the motorists of rural and regional Australia.
In the mid-year budget review, we learnt that the cost of the fuel grants scheme had blown out considerably. It appears that, rather than costing the government $500 million over four years, it will now cost more like $1 billion. The question is: why has the fuel grants scheme blown out so extensively? The government's response is that Treasury simply underestimated the number of retail outlets that were likely to be eligible for the scheme. That is absolute rubbish.
